newsitem.title: USA: Congressmen urge continued Mexican truck curbs.
newsitem.headline: Congressmen urge continued Mexican truck curbs.

text.p: A bipartisan group of 201 Congressmen urged President Clinton in a letter released on Monday to retain the existing restrictions for safety reasons on trucking between the United States and Mexico.

The 167 Democrats and 34 Republicans said the curbs remain needed to protect the the traveling public, and withholding full border state access for Mexican trucks has not held back the growth of U.S.-Mexican trade.
Open access was to have gone into effect in 1995 as part of the North American Free Trade Agreement but was delayed by Clinton on grounds that many Mexican trucks were unsafe.
The Congressional letter comes ahead of a NAFTA commission meeting this week and Clinton's scheduled summit with Mexican President Ernesto Zedilla on April 11-12.

"Despite overly optimistic reports to the contrary, there has not been sufficient progress in addressing safety deficiencies to justify expanding privileges for Mexican motor carriers," the Congressmen told Clinton.
"Declarations that all trucks, U.S. or foreign, must meet U.S. safety standards are meaningless without adequate oversight by competent inspectors," they said.
